{"ScriptContent":"#!/bin/sh

# Script to concatenate rules files found in a base audit rules directory
# to form a single /etc/audit/audit.rules file suitable for loading into
# the Linux audit system

# When forming the interim rules file, both empty lines and comment
# lines (starting with # or <whitespace>#) are stripped as the source files
# are processed.
#
# Having formed the interim rules file, the script checks if the file is empty
# or is identical to the existing /etc/audit/audit.rules and if either of
# these cases are true, it does not replace the existing file
#

# Variables
#
# DestinationFile:
#   Destination rules file
# SourceRulesDir:
#   Directory location to find component rule files
# TmpRules:
#   Temporary interim rules file
# ASuffix:
#   Suffix for previous audit.rules file if this script replaces it.
#   The file is left in the destination directory with suffix with $ASuffix

DestinationFile=/etc/audit/audit.rules
SourceRulesDir=/etc/audit/rules.d
TmpRules=$(mktemp /tmp/aurules.XXXXXXXX)
ASuffix="prev"
OnlyCheck=0
LoadRules=0
RETVAL=0
usage="Usage: $0 [--check|--load]"

# Delete the interim file on faults
trap 'rm -f ${TmpRules}; exit 1' 1 2 3 13 15

try_load() {
	if [ $LoadRules -eq 1 ] ; then
		/sbin/auditctl -R ${DestinationFile}
		RETVAL=$?
	fi
}

while [ $# -ge 1 ]
do
	if [ "$1" = "--check" ] ; then
		OnlyCheck=1
	elif [ "$1" = "--load" ] ; then
		LoadRules=1
	else
		echo "$usage"
		exit 1
	fi
	shift
done

# Check environment
if [ ! -d ${SourceRulesDir} ]; then
	echo "$0: No rules directory - ${SourceRulesDir}"
	rm -f "${TmpRules}"
	try_load
	exit 1
fi

# Create the interim rules file ensuring its access modes protect it
# from normal users and strip empty lines and comment lines. We also ensure
#   - the last processed -D directive without an option is emitted as the first
#     line. -D directives with options are left in place
#   - the last processed -b directory is emitted as the second line
#   - the last processed -f directory is emitted as the third line
#   - the last processed -e directive is emitted as the last line
umask 0137
echo "## This file is automatically generated from $SourceRulesDir" >> "${TmpRules}"
for rules in $(/bin/ls -1v ${SourceRulesDir} | grep "\.rules$") ; do
	cat ${SourceRulesDir}/"${rules}"
done | awk '
BEGIN   {
        minus_e = "";
        minus_D = "";
        minus_f = "";
        minus_b = "";
        rest = 0;
} {
        sub(/\r$/, "");
        if (length($0) < 1) { next; }
        if (match($0, "^\\s*#")) { next; }
        if (match($0, "^\\s*-e")) { minus_e = $0; next; }
        if (match($0, "^\\s*-D\\s*$")) { minus_D = $0; next; }
        if (match($0, "^\\s*-f")) { minus_f = $0; next; }
        if (match($0, "^\\s*-b")) { minus_b = $0; next; }
        rules[rest++] = $0;
}
END     {
        printf "%s\n%s\n%s\n", minus_D, minus_b, minus_f;
        for (i = 0; i < rest; i++) { printf "%s\n", rules[i]; }
        printf "%s\n", minus_e;
}' >> "${TmpRules}"

# If empty then quit
if [ ! -s "${TmpRules}" ]; then
	echo "$0: No rules"
	rm -f "${TmpRules}"
	try_load
	exit $RETVAL
fi

# If the same then quit
cmp -s "${TmpRules}" ${DestinationFile} > /dev/null 2>&1
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
	echo "$0: No change"
	rm -f "${TmpRules}"
	try_load
	exit $RETVAL
elif [ $OnlyCheck -eq 1 ] ; then
	echo "$0: Rules have changed and should be updated"
	rm -f "${TmpRules}"
	exit 0
fi

# Otherwise we install the new file
if [ -f ${DestinationFile} ]; then
	cp ${DestinationFile} ${DestinationFile}.${ASuffix}
fi
# We copy the file so that it gets the right selinux lable
cp "${TmpRules}" ${DestinationFile}
chmod 0640 ${DestinationFile}
# Restore context on MLS system. /tmp is SystemLow & audit.rules is SystemHigh
if [ -x /sbin/restorecon ] ; then
	/sbin/restorecon -F ${DestinationFile}
fi
rm -f "${TmpRules}"

try_load
exit $RETVAL
"}

all_attempts.query_llm:
union DeviceProcessEvents, DeviceEvents
| where ( (isnotempty(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) and tolower(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) has "auditctl")
       or (isnotempty(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) and tolower(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) has "auditd")
       or (isnotempty(ProcessCommandLine) and tolower(ProcessCommandLine) has "auditctl")
       or (isnotempty(ProcessCommandLine) and tolower(ProcessCommandLine) has "auditd")
       or (tostring(AdditionalFields) has "auditctl")
       or (tostring(AdditionalFields) has "auditd") )
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, DeviceId, InitiatingProcessFileName, InitiatingProcessCommandLine, ProcessCommandLine, AdditionalFields, Type
| sort by TimeGenerated desc
all_attempts.query_executed:
union DeviceProcessEvents_CL, DeviceEvents_CL
| where ( (isnotempty(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) and tolower(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) has "auditctl")
       or (isnotempty(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) and tolower(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) has "auditd")
       or (isnotempty(ProcessCommandLine) and tolower(ProcessCommandLine) has "auditctl")
       or (isnotempty(ProcessCommandLine) and tolower(ProcessCommandLine) has "auditd")
       or (tostring(AdditionalFields) has "auditctl")
       or (tostring(AdditionalFields) has "auditd") )
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, DeviceId, InitiatingProcessFileName, InitiatingProcessCommandLine, ProcessCommandLine, AdditionalFields, Type
| sort by TimeGenerated desc
all_attempts.explanation: This query uses a union of DeviceProcessEvents (which records process execution events) and DeviceEvents (which may contain Syslog or other relevant data) to identify any events that mention commands used to disable the audit subsystem on a Linux host. It filters events where either the InitiatingProcessCommandLine or ProcessCommandLine contains key strings such as 'auditctl' or 'auditd'. Adjust or add more strings if needed to capture any variations like 'systemctl stop auditd' or 'service auditd stop'. The results are projected to show relevant fields (timestamp, device name, command lines, etc.) and sorted with the most recent events first.
all_attempts.result_summary: The results include several entries, one of which clearly shows a command invocation via 'sh -c "auditctl -e 0"'. This command disables audit functionality.

test_case.prompt: During investigation of a Linux device, you see evidence of a process that reports system locale details. Identify the tool used.
test_case.KQL_query:
DeviceProcessEvents
| where FileName =~ "localectl" or ProcessCommandLine contains "localectl"
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, FileName, ProcessCommandLine, AccountName
| order by TimeGenerated desc
test_case.context: On a Linux host, an adversary ran a command to report the system language settings.
test_case.objective: Determine which utility was invoked to discover the system locale.

technical_details.command_analysis: Search process execution logs for a command that queries locale information.
technical_details.detection_approach: Filter DeviceProcessEvents for FileName or ProcessCommandLine entries related to the locale discovery command.

test_case.thinking_how_to_phrase_question_and_answ: Phrase the question so that the analyst focuses on finding the name of the tool executed without giving away specific query syntax.
test_case.KQL_validation_message: KQL query validation successful: The query results have a row with 'FileName' as 'localectl' and matching command line invocation ('localectl status'), providing direct evidence for 'localectl' activity as expected in the answer. Additionally, other rows demonstrate 'localectl' executed via 'dash', further supporting visibility of this command. Thus, the results meet the requirements for the detection question.

query_result.query:
DeviceProcessEvents
| where ProcessCommandLine has "locale"
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, FileName, ProcessCommandLine
| summarize EventCount = count() by FileName, ProcessCommandLine
| sort by EventCount desc

test_case.prompt: An attacker on a Linux host has attempted to turn off command history by modifying an environment variable. Using process execution logs, determine the exact shell command used to set HISTSIZE to zero.
test_case.context: On Linux systems, adversaries may disable shell history by adjusting the HISTSIZE environment variable to zero, preventing commands from being recorded.
test_case.objective: Detect when a shell session sets HISTSIZE to zero to evade history logging.

technical_details.command_analysis: Look for shell process executions where the ProcessCommandLine includes an export of HISTSIZE set to zero.
technical_details.detection_approach: Query the DeviceProcessEvents table for sh or bash invocations whose command line contains the string “export HISTSIZE=0”.

test_case.thinking_how_to_phrase_question_and_answ: Consider which table stores process creation events on Linux and how environment variable exports appear in the command line field. Formulate a query to filter for these specific export commands.
test_case.KQL_validation_message: KQL query validation successful: The provided query results specifically include a row where the 'ProcessCommandLine' contains 'export HISTSIZE=0', exactly as expected. This indicates that the KQL query has captured the precise activity needed to answer the detection question, with supporting contextual fields (e.g., DeviceName, AccountName) also present. Therefore, these results are sufficient and directly responsive to the detection requirement.

query_result.query:
DeviceProcessEvents
| where ProcessCommandLine contains "HISTSIZE=0"
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, ProcessCommandLine
raw_results: sh -c 'echo $HISTSIZE; export HISTSIZE=0; echo "runnning some commands to populate the history"; whoami; groups; if [ $(echo $HISTSIZE) -eq 0 ]; then echo "\\$HISTSIZE is zero"; else HIST_LENGTH=$(wc -l $HISTFILE); echo "\\$HISTSIZE is not zero, history size is $HIST_LENGTH";  fi'

sh -c 'echo $HISTSIZE; export HISTSIZE=0; echo "runnning some commands to populate the history"; whoami; groups; if [ $(echo $HISTSIZE) -eq 0 ]; then echo "\\$HISTSIZE is zero"; else HIST_LENGTH=$(wc -l $HISTFILE); echo "\\$HISTSIZE is not zero, history size is $HIST_LENGTH";  fi'

test_case.prompt: A .NET tracing environment variable was turned off in a user’s registry on a Windows system. Which built-in command-line tool was used to make this registry change?
test_case.KQL_query:
let Exec = DeviceProcessEvents
| where TimeGenerated >= ago(30d)
| where FileName == "reg.exe"
| where ProcessCommandLine has_any ("add","HKCU\\Environment","COMPlus_ETWEnabled")
| where ProcessCommandLine has_any ("/d 0","0x0","dword:00000000")
| extend Tool = FileName;
let Reg = DeviceRegistryEvents
| where TimeGenerated >= ago(30d)
| where ActionType contains "SetValue"
| where RegistryKey has_any ("HKCU\\Environment","HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Environment")
| where RegistryValueName == "COMPlus_ETWEnabled"
| where RegistryValueData in ("0","0x0") or RegistryValueData has "00000000"
| extend Tool = InitiatingProcessFileName;
Exec
| union Reg
| summarize Count = count() by Tool
| sort by Count desc

test_case.thinking_how_to_phrase_question_and_answ: Frame the question around identifying which Windows utility wrote to the registry key that disables .NET event tracing. The expected answer should be the exact process name used.
test_case.KQL_validation_message: KQL query validation successful: The query results include the 'Tool' column with a value of 'reg.exe', which matches the expected answer exactly. test_case.prompt: Using Linux process or syslog logs, identify the executable that was run to output the system's locale information.
test_case.KQL_query:
let LinuxDevices = DeviceInfo
| where OSPlatform == "Linux"
| project DeviceId, DeviceName;

let LocaleProc = DeviceProcessEvents
| where DeviceId in (LinuxDevices | project DeviceId)
| where isnotempty(ProcessCommandLine)
| extend args = split(trim(" ", ProcessCommandLine), " ")
| where args[0] == "locale" and array_length(args) == 1
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, AccountName = InitiatingProcessAccountName, CommandLine = ProcessCommandLine;

let LocaleSys = Syslog
| where Computer in (LinuxDevices | project DeviceName)
| where ProcessName == "locale"
| where SyslogMessage has "LANG=" or SyslogMessage has "LC_"
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName = Computer, AccountName = "", CommandLine = SyslogMessage;

LocaleProc
| union LocaleSys
| sort by TimeGenerated desc

test_case.prompt: A Linux host was probed by reading its locale configuration file to discover the system language. Identify which tool was invoked to perform that read operation.
test_case.KQL_query:
let localePaths = dynamic(["/etc/locale.conf","/etc/default/locale"]);
union
(
    DeviceProcessEvents
    | where FileName == "cat"
    | where ProcessCommandLine has_any (localePaths)
    | extend Device = DeviceName, CommandLine = ProcessCommandLine, Source = "DeviceProcessEvents", Account = InitiatingProcessAccountName
),
(
    Syslog
    | where ProcessName == "cat"
    | where SyslogMessage has_any (localePaths)
    | extend Device = HostName, CommandLine = SyslogMessage, Source = "Syslog", Account = ""
)
| project TimeGenerated, Device, Account, FileName, CommandLine, Source
| sort by TimeGenerated desc

test_case.prompt: On a Windows system, identify any PowerShell Test-NetConnection executions against an uncommon port. Which port number was checked?
test_case.KQL_query:
let testNet = DeviceProcessEvents
| where FileName in ("powershell.exe","pwsh.exe")
| where tolower(ProcessCommandLine) contains "test-netconnection"
| where ProcessCommandLine matches regex @"-port\s+\d+"
| extend TestedPort = toint(extract(@"-port\s+(\d+)", 1, ProcessCommandLine))
| where TestedPort !in (80,443,3389)
| project DeviceId, InitiatingProcessId = ProcessId, Time = TimeGenerated, TestedPort, Account = InitiatingProcessAccountName, CommandLine = ProcessCommandLine;
testNet
| join kind=inner (
    DeviceNetworkEvents
    | project DeviceId, InitiatingProcessId, NetworkTime = TimeGenerated, RemoteIP, RemotePort
) on DeviceId, InitiatingProcessId
| where RemotePort == TestedPort and NetworkTime between (Time - 5m .. Time + 5m)
| project NetworkTime, DeviceId, Account, TestedPort, RemoteIP, RemotePort, CommandLine
test_case.context: Windows environments support native PowerShell cmdlets for connectivity checks, which can be abused by adversaries to probe uncommon network ports.
test_case.objective: Detect when PowerShell’s Test-NetConnection is leveraged to test connectivity to a non-standard port on a remote host.

technical_details.command_analysis: The Test-NetConnection cmdlet is invoked with a specified ComputerName and Port argument, performing a TCP/ICMP probe; the command line includes “-port <number>”.
technical_details.detection_approach: Search Windows process or network events for PowerShell invocations containing “Test-NetConnection” and extract the port argument; correlate with any outbound connection or network event records to confirm the port tested.

test_case.thinking_how_to_phrase_question_and_answ: Frame the question to ask which numeric port was probed by a PowerShell Test-NetConnection execution, expecting the exact port number (e.g., 8081).
test_case.KQL_validation_message: KQL query validation successful: The query results show multiple rows with both 'TestedPort' and 'RemotePort' set to 8081, and the command line used includes '-port 8081'. This directly corresponds to the expected answer of "8081", demonstrating that the port 8081 was tested in these activities. Therefore, the results provide direct evidence needed to answer the detection question as specified by the expected answer.

all_attempts.query_llm:
DeviceProcessEvents
| where InitiatingProcessCommandLine has "Test-NetConnection"
| extend PortChecked = tostring(extract(@"(?i)-Port\s+(\d+)", 1, InitiatingProcessCommandLine))
| where isnotempty(PortChecked) and PortChecked !in ("80", "443")
| summarize ExecutionCount=count() by PortChecked
| project PortChecked, ExecutionCount

| summarize ExecutionCount=count() by PortChecked
| project PortChecked, ExecutionCount

It filters by looking for 'Test-NetConnection' in the initiating process command line. Then, it uses a regex to extract the port number specified with the '-Port' parameter. Finally, it excludes common ports (80 and 443) to focus on uncommon ports and summarizes the results by the extracted port number. You can adjust the common ports filter as needed.

test_case.prompt: On a Windows device, an attacker ran a PowerShell script to collect system settings including UI language and locale. Identify which cmdlet in the command line was used to obtain the system locale.
test_case.KQL_query:
DeviceProcessEvents
| where FileName in ("powershell.exe", "pwsh.exe")
| where ProcessCommandLine has "Get-WinSystemLocale"
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, AccountName, ProcessCommandLine
test_case.context: A Windows host where an adversary ran a PowerShell script to enumerate various system configuration settings such as UI language, user language preferences, system locale, current culture, UI culture, and time zone.
test_case.objective: Detect execution of the PowerShell cmdlet used to retrieve the system locale.

technical_details.command_analysis: The script builds a hash table with entries like UILanguage = Get-WinUILanguageOverride, SystemLocale = Get-WinSystemLocale, CurrentCulture = [System.Globalization.CultureInfo]::CurrentCulture.Name, and then outputs each key-value pair.
technical_details.detection_approach: Query DeviceProcessEvents for PowerShell processes where the command line includes the Get-WinSystemLocale cmdlet to spot attempts to enumerate the system locale.

test_case.thinking_how_to_phrase_question_and_answ: Consider which process event table and fields capture the full PowerShell command line, then filter for the specific cmdlet that retrieves system locale.
test_case.KQL_validation_message: KQL query validation successful: The ProcessCommandLine field in the query results shows a PowerShell command which includes 'Get-WinSystemLocale', matching the expected answer. This indicates that the command in question was indeed executed, which provides the evidence needed to detect the activity described.

DeviceProcessEvents

| extend ExtractedCmdlet = extract(cmdRegex, 1, InitiatingProcessCommandLine)
| where isnotempty(ExtractedCmdlet)
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, InitiatingProcessCommandLine, ExtractedCmdlet

test_case.prompt: On Windows, following a phantom DLL hijack of the Print Spooler service, determine which system file was first copied from its original location before being renamed for persistence.
test_case.KQL_query:
DeviceFileEvents
| where ActionType in ("FileCopied","FileMoved","FileRenamed")
| where
    (
        FileName == "amsi.dll"
        and ActionType == "FileCopied"
        and PreviousFolderPath has "\\Windows\\System32\\"
        and FolderPath has "\\Users\\"
    )
    or
    (
        FileName == "ualapi.dll"
        and (
            (ActionType == "FileRenamed" and PreviousFileName == "amsi.dll" and FolderPath has "\\Users\\")
            or
            (ActionType in ("FileCopied","FileMoved") and PreviousFolderPath has "\\Users\\" and FolderPath has "\\Windows\\System32\\")
        )
    )
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, ActionType, FileName, PreviousFileName, FolderPath, PreviousFolderPath, InitiatingProcessCommandLine
| order by TimeGenerated desc
test_case.context: An attacker exploits Windows Print Spooler to establish persistence by deploying a renamed system DLL.
test_case.objective: Identify which system DLL was copied from its native location before being renamed and persisted in the system directory.

technical_details.command_analysis: An attacker uses command-prompt to copy C:\Windows\System32\amsi.dll to a user profile, renames it to ualapi.dll, and then moves it back into System32, followed by configuring the Spooler service to auto-start.
technical_details.detection_approach: Search DeviceFileEvents for copy or rename operations involving ‘amsi.dll’ and ‘ualapi.dll’ between the System32 and user directories, examining fields like FileName, FolderPath, and PreviousFileName.

test_case.thinking_how_to_phrase_question_and_answ: Pose the question to require analysts to query file events without naming the DLL explicitly, ensuring they build a KQL query to pinpoint the original file.
test_case.KQL_validation_message: KQL query validation successful: The query results feature a FileRenamed action where 'amsi.dll' appears as the PreviousFileName, and 'ualapi.dll' as the new FileName. This aligns exactly with the expected answer of 'amsi.dll', confirming the activity involving the file. The supporting details in InitiatingProcessCommandLine also reference copying and renaming 'amsi.dll'. Thus, the results directly provide the evidence described in the expected answers.
KQL_query_results: "cmd.exe" /c copy %windir%\System32\amsi.dll %APPDATA%\amsi.dll & ren %APPDATA%\amsi.dll ualapi.dll & copy %APPDATA%\ualapi.dll %windir%\System32\ualapi.dll & sc config Spooler start=auto

The results are sorted by the event timestamp in ascending order so that the earliest (first) such event is returned. You can set the timerange when running this query.

all_attempts.explanation: This query leverages the DeviceFileEvents table to look for file rename events where the file’s previous location is in one of the Windows system directories (System32 or SysWOW64). It converts the PreviousFolderPath field to lowercase to avoid case sensitivity issues. The query then sorts the events by TimeGenerated in ascending order and selects the first event. This helps identify which system file was first copied (as indicated by its original system directory location) before being renamed for persistence in a phantom DLL hijack of the Print Spooler service.

This query attempts to find the first event where a system file (i.e. originating from a Windows system folder) was copied (as evidenced by a FileCreated event) and later renamed (FileRenamed event) for persistence. In the first step, we extract FileCreated events (the presumed copy) from either c:\windows\system32 or c:\windows\syswow64 (case-insensitively). In a second step we filter for FileRenamed events. We then join these two sets on the file hash (MD5) and device (DeviceId) to correlate the copy with the subsequent rename. We further ensure that the copy event happened before the rename event. Finally, we order by the copy time ascending and return the earliest such occurrence, projecting key fields from both events.
all_attempts.result_summary: The results include a row with OriginalFileName 'wpbbin.exe' and OriginalPath 'C:\Windows\System32\wpbbin.exe', which indicates that 'wpbbin.exe' is the system file involved in the event.

test_case.prompt: On the Windows device, a security check was run to detect debugger processes via PowerShell. Which tool (process) carried out this check?
test_case.KQL_query:
DeviceProcessEvents
| where TimeGenerated >= ago(7d)
| where FileName == "powershell.exe"
| where ProcessCommandLine has_any("Get-Process","dbg","debug","System.Diagnostics.Debugger","IsAttached","EncodedCommand")
| extend Tool = replace(@"\.exe$","", FileName)
| summarize InvocationCount = count() by Tool
| order by InvocationCount desc
test_case.context: A Windows host where a PowerShell-based script was executed to detect debugger processes by enumerating running processes for names containing “dbg” or “debug” and checking the .NET debugger attachment flag.
test_case.objective: Identify the tool used to perform the debugger presence check on the endpoint.

technical_details.command_analysis: The PowerShell snippet lists processes whose names match substrings “dbg” or “debug” and evaluates [System.Diagnostics.Debugger]::IsAttached to detect an attached debugger.
technical_details.detection_approach: Search DeviceProcessEvents for the PowerShell execution that performed this enumeration and extract the initiating process file name.

test_case.thinking_how_to_phrase_question_and_answ: Guide the analyst to query process creation events on Windows, filter for the PowerShell command execution, and then retrieve the name of the executable that initiated the debugger check.
test_case.KQL_validation_message: KQL query validation successful: The results have a row with 'powershell' in the 'Tool' field and an associated count, which provides evidence that 'powershell' activity was detected. This aligns directly with the expected answers, so the necessary information is included.

query_result.query:
union withsource=EventSource DeviceProcessEvents, DeviceEvents
| where FileName =~ "powershell.exe"
| extend PS_CmdLine = tolower(tostring(ProcessCommandLine)), Init_CmdLine = tolower(tostring(InitiatingProcessCommandLine))
// Look for mentions of debug in either the PowerShell process or its initiator's command line
| where PS_CmdLine contains "debug" or Init_CmdLine contains "debug"
// Summarize by the initiating process name, which is the tool that launched PowerShell
| summarize EventCount = count() by InitiatingProcessFileName, EventSource
| order by EventCount desc

all_attempts.query_llm:
DeviceProcessEvents
| where FileName =~ "powershell.exe"
| where tolower(InitiatingProcessCommandLine) contains "debug"
| summarize EventCount = count() by InitiatingProcessFileName
| order by EventCount desc
all_attempts.query_executed:

test_case.prompt: In a Windows environment, locate any occurrences where an elevated DISM utility was run to enumerate the system’s international (locale) settings. What was the exact command line used?
test_case.KQL_query:
DeviceProcessEvents
| where ActionType == "ProcessCreated"
| where isnotempty(ProcessCommandLine)
| where ProcessCommandLine has "dism.exe" and ProcessCommandLine has "/Online" and ProcessCommandLine has "/Get-Intl"
| extend DetectedCommand = extract(@"(?i)(dism\.exe\s+/online\s+/get-intl)", 1, ProcessCommandLine)
| where isnotempty(DetectedCommand)
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, AccountName, ProcessId, DetectedCommand
| order by TimeGenerated desc
test_case.context: On Windows systems, DISM (Deployment Image Servicing and Management) can be invoked with elevated privileges to enumerate international settings. Adversaries may abuse this legitimate tool to fingerprint system locales.
test_case.objective: Identify when DISM was executed to query system language settings and surface the exact command used.

technical_details.command_analysis: The dism.exe binary is launched with the /online and /Get-Intl flags to list locale information.
technical_details.detection_approach: Search the DeviceProcessEvents table for dism.exe process creations with a command line containing both "/online" and "/Get-Intl".

test_case.thinking_how_to_phrase_question_and_answ: Phrase the question to ask specifically what full command invocation was used to retrieve language information, and expect the answer to match the exact dism.exe invocation recorded in the logs.
test_case.KQL_validation_message: KQL query validation successful: The expected answer was the command 'dism.exe /online /Get-Intl'. The results include two rows where 'DetectedCommand' is 'dism.exe  /online /Get-Intl' (with a double space) and 'dism.exe /online /Get-Intl' (single space). Both strings indicate that this command was executed, confirming the presence of this activity. The evidence in the results matches the detection question fully.

all_attempts.query_llm:
DeviceProcessEvents
| where FileName has "dism.exe"
| where ProcessCommandLine has "/Get-Intl" or InitiatingProcessCommandLine has "/Get-Intl"
| where ProcessTokenElevation == "High" or InitiatingProcessTokenElevation == "High"
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, AccountName, ProcessCommandLine, InitiatingProcessCommandLine
| extend ExactCommandLine = coalesce(ProcessCommandLine, InitiatingProcessCommandLine)
all_attempts.query_executed:
DeviceProcessEvents_CL
| where FileName has "dism.exe"
| where ProcessCommandLine has "/Get-Intl" or InitiatingProcessCommandLine has "/Get-Intl"
| where ProcessTokenElevation == "High" or InitiatingProcessTokenElevation == "High"
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, AccountName, ProcessCommandLine, InitiatingProcessCommandLine
| extend ExactCommandLine = coalesce(ProcessCommandLine, InitiatingProcessCommandLine)
all_attempts.explanation: This query searches for events in the DeviceProcessEvents table where the DISM utility (dism.exe) was executed with a command line that includes the parameter for enumerating international (locale) settings (i.e. '/Get-Intl'). It also filters for events likely executed with elevated permissions by checking for tokens indicating elevation. The query returns the exact command line, along with key context such as TimeGenerated, DeviceName, and AccountName. Adjust the query as needed if additional filtering for elevation is required, as the elevation field values may vary in your environment.

all_attempts.query_llm:
DeviceProcessEvents

| where ProcessTokenElevation == "High" or InitiatingProcessTokenElevation == "High"
| extend ExactCommandLine = coalesce(ProcessCommandLine, InitiatingProcessCommandLine)
| project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, AccountName, ExactCommandLine

It filters on events where the process or its initiating process was elevated (i.e. TokenElevation is 'High'). Finally, it uses the coalesce function to show the exact command line that was used, and projects relevant fields for review.

all_attempts.query_llm:
union isfuzzy=true DeviceProcessEvents, DeviceEvents

| where tolower(coalesce(ProcessCommandLine, InitiatingProcessCommandLine)) contains "/get-intl"
| where coalesce(ProcessTokenElevation, InitiatingProcessTokenElevation) == "High"

all_attempts.explanation: This query searches for events where the DISM utility (dism.exe) was executed with a command line containing '/get-intl' (which is used to enumerate a system’s international (locale) settings) and where the process was elevated (i.e. its token elevation is 'High'). To cover the possibility that the command line is present either in the ProcessCommandLine or in the InitiatingProcessCommandLine fields, we use the coalesce function. We also perform a case insensitive match using tolower() for both the file name and the command line. In addition, the query uses a union of DeviceProcessEvents and DeviceEvents since either table may register the event of interest. The query projects TimeGenerated, DeviceName, AccountName, and the exact command line used.

| where tolower(coalesce(ProcessTokenElevation, InitiatingProcessTokenElevation)) == "high"

all_attempts.explanation: The following KQL query searches for Windows events where a process executed dism.exe with an elevated token (i.e. ProcessTokenElevation equals 'High') and its command line contains the /get-intl parameter. It union’s (using isfuzzy=true) two common tables where process command lines are logged (DeviceProcessEvents and DeviceEvents) and uses tolower() on both the FileName and ProcessCommandLine (or InitiatingProcessCommandLine) fields to ensure the search is case-insensitive. Finally, it projects the time stamp, device name, account name, and the exact command line used. This query should be run with the appropriate timerange to search for the relevant time period. Note: If no results are returned, please verify that the logging captures the exact command line parameters used for enumeration, as they might differ slightly (such as having additional parameters).

all_attempts.explanation: This query unions data from DeviceProcessEvents and DeviceEvents (using isfuzzy union to cover differences in data sources). It then normalizes the FileName field (using coalesce with InitiatingProcessFileName) to ensure we capture the proper filename (dism.exe). Next, it extracts the command line (from either ProcessCommandLine or InitiatingProcessCommandLine) and checks if it contains the '/get-intl' parameter (in lower case to make the search case insensitive). The query further checks that the token elevation field (from either ProcessTokenElevation or InitiatingProcessTokenElevation) equals 'high' (indicating an elevated process). Finally, it projects the relevant fields, including the TimeGenerated, DeviceName, AccountName, and the ExactCommandLine used. Adjusting the timerange in the function call will allow you to narrow down the results.
